I really enjoyed this video but here's some food for thought. You went on saying how valuable the IU Pac naming system is entire video and then at the end said that looking things up and in the end was the best option. I would like to note that the name of a molecule is not only useful for chemists. Having some context with respect to the chemicals origin might be useful in other fields. I'm not making a claim that one way is better than the other simply put I see utility in both.  I think it would be cool if a fusion if you had for example cinnamaldehyde and then be chemical nomenclature part. With respect to chemicals being Universal that is a very good point and something that should be taken into consideration  when giving the chemical origin name part

at 6:43 I think this molecule should be called "trans-2-methylbut-2-enoic acid" or "(Z)-2-methylbut-2-enoic acid".
If you are using cis and trans system to name this, you just need to find two identical groups, which in this case is methyl groups and they are on the opposite side of double bond. Therefore it is a trans molecule. However IUPAC suggest a more advanced way of naming it which is E-Z system. If you are using E-Z system you can just compare the atomic number (if atomic number are the same then compare the mass number) i.e. I>Br>Cl>S>P>F>O>N>C>T>D>H etc. If the first atoms directly attached to the double bond carbon are the same then compare the atom that has greatest atomic number attached to it and so on and so forth. So in this case the groups with higher priority attached to both end of double bond carbons are on the same side. Therefore it is a (Z) molecule.

I think so many students find these videos, and similar youtube videos so helpful is because you have already learnt this in class. Hearing it for the first time is always so much more confusing, but having it solidified in a different format and with a different perspective makes all the difference.

This is mainly because I'm trying to study chemistry on my own (screw you GAMSAT), and watching CrashCourse when trying to learn a new topic for the first time, I find I actually learn very little.

So, whilst CrashCourse is a great resource to catch your interest in the sciences, or as a quick refresher for students, it is pretty bad for people learning it the first time. So if you're having a lot of trouble learning, its not you. Keep studying, and it'll make sense soon enough :)

In case anyone was wondering about the exact precedence of the functional groups listed in this video (ranked in decreasing priority):

#1 Carboxylic Acid
#2 Esters
#3 Aldehydes
#4 Ketones
#5 Alcohols
#6 Amines

I've found something similar to the topic you spoke about at 1:40-2:05. In 1668, John Wilkins tried to create a language in which each word represented the thing itself. For instance, Zi identifies the Genus of “beasts” (mammals); Zit gives the Difference of “rapacious beasts of the dog kind”; Zitα gives the Species of dogs. (Sometimes the first letter indicates a supercategory— e.g. Z always indicates an animal.)

I hate to nitpick, but since this video is about nitpicking when it comes IUPAC names I feel slightly better pointing it out... but use of cis/trans naming for double bonds with more than 2 substituents isn't IUPAC's preferred method, should be using the E/Z notation since it's completely unambiguous. In this case angelic acid should be (Z)-2-methylbut-2-enoic acid. Obviously cis/trans is easier (especially when teaching this stuff) but it's worth being aware of :)

When you say add "-one" onto ethane to make ethanone isn't that incorrect? A ketone needs at least one carbon on either side of the carbonyl, ethane with two carbons can only be an aldehyde. The smallest ketone is propanone.

I've always hated common names and preferred the systematic naming system of IUPAC.  It's easier and more sensible to learn a system than to learn bunches of individual names for chemicals.  Unless you're working with a chemical on a regular basis, IUPAC names are better, especially when you're learning chemistry.

Want to lose weight?  Say the IUPAC name of table sugar before consuming it.
 (2R,3R,4S,5S,6R)2[(2S,3S,4S,5R)3,4-dihydroxy-2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)oxolan-2-yl]oxy-6(hydroxymethyl)oxane-3,4,5-triol

E/Z, "fennel" not "phenol", "ene al" not "enol" or "anol", Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority for double bonds and stereocenters, and cinnamaldehyde is still technically correct- it's just recognized as a historical name. It's easier to say for chemists, even if less informative. Much like the acetyl-/acet- prefix, sometimes old names are more convenient. I may be over-pedantic, but the whole point of educational videos is to teach.
